'''Martin Christopher Kennedy''' (17 June 1962 – 1 November 2016), known as '''Bap Kennedy''', was a singer-songwriter from [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland.<ref name="artistdirect">{{cite web|url=http://www.artistdirect.com/nad/music/artist/bio/0,,661979,00.html|publisher=artistdirect.com|title=Bap Kennedy biography|accessdate=26 January 2009}}</ref> He was noted for his collaborations with [[Steve Earle]], [[Van Morrison]], [[Shane MacGowan]]<ref name="artistdirect"/> and [[Mark Knopfler]],<ref name="Mark Knopfler">{{cite web|url= http://www.markknopfler.com/discography/bap-kennedy|publisher=markknopfler.com|title=Mark Knopfler discography|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> as well as for writing the song "Moonlight Kiss" which was on the soundtrack for the film ''[[Serendipity (film)|Serendipity]]''.<ref name="newsletter">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/what-s-on/music/it-was-fun-to-revisit-my-more-upbeat-self-1-5835720|publisher=newsletter.com|title=Bap Kennedy interview|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

Kennedy was in the rock band [[Energy Orchard]]<ref name="biography">{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/bio.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Biography: Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> for many years and also recorded a number of well-received solo albums including ''[[Domestic Blues]]'', ''[[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]]'', ''[[The Sailor's Revenge]],'' ''Let's Start Again'' and ''Reckless Heart''.<ref name="biography"/> During his solo career, Kennedy performed, wrote and recorded songs with artists such as [[Steve Earle]] (on ''Domestic Blues''), [[Van Morrison]] (on ''The Big Picture'') and [[Mark Knopfler]] (on ''The Sailor's Revenge'').<ref name="artistdirect"/> Following the releases of ''The Big Picture'' and ''The Sailor's Revenge'', he toured the US and Europe with [[Mark Knopfler]] of [[Dire Straits]],<ref name="biography"/> who also produced Kennedy's 2012 album ''The Sailor's Revenge''.<ref name="artistdirect"/>

==Musical career==
===Early musical career and 10 Past 7 (1978–87)===
Kennedy's first band was the punk band Sellout formed in 1978 at age 16.  The band was formed to support rock group Uncle Waldo, playing in a local [[Belfast]] club.<ref name="cdbaby">{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/bapkennedy1|publisher=cdbaby.com|title=The Big Picture|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

In 1980 after having played in several other local bands, Kennedy formed the band 10 past 7,<ref name="triste">{{cite web|url=http://www.triste.co.uk/artkennedy.htm|publisher=triste.com|title=Bap Kennedy – too long in exile|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> with whom he received his first national recognition when they appeared on [[Channel 4]] music show [[The Tube (1982 TV series)|The Tube]] in 1983.<ref name="Irish rock">{{cite web|url=http://www.irishrock.org/irodb/bands/tenpastseven.html|publisher=irishrock.org|title=10 Past 7|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> The band was managed by Mark Kelly, {{small|[[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]}}.<ref name="biography"/> 10 Past 7 were signed to the [[Good Vibrations (record label)|Good Vibrations]] record label by [[Terri Hooley]]<ref name="Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/bap-kennedy-brian-is-more-showbiz-than-me-30049175.html |work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=Brian is more showbiz than me|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> – who had discovered [[The Undertones]] several years earlier<ref name="Belfast Telegraph July 2011">{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/film-tv/news/story-of-terri-hooley-belfasts-godfather-of-punk-to-hit-silver-screen-28640706.html|work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=Story of Terri Hooley, Belfast's godfather of punk, to hit silver screen|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> – and they released two singles<ref name="Irish rock"/> before disbanding when Bap left Belfast for London to pursue a recording contract.<ref name="biography"/>

===Energy Orchard (1987–96)===
{{Main|Energy Orchard}}
In 1987, after moving to London, Kennedy formed the band [[Energy Orchard]], for whom he was the rhythm guitarist, lead singer and primary songwriter.<ref name="biography"/> Although the band was based in London, all of its members had originally come from Belfast like Kennedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/394165-Energy-Orchard|publisher=discogs|title=Energy Orchard|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> [[MCA Records]] gave the band a major record deal in 1988 and they would go on to release two albums with the label, before signing with [[Transatlantic Records|Transatlantic]] for a further two studio albums as well as the live album ''Orchardville''.<ref name="cdbaby"/>

Energy Orchard went on to establish themselves as regulars on the live scene in London, including a performance at the first London [[Fleadh Cheoil|Fleadh]] in 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/event/1125119+Fleadh+1990|publisher=last.fm|title=Fleadh 1990|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> The band also toured extensively throughout the UK, Europe and America, including several support slots with [[Van Morrison]], [[Steve Earle]] and [[Jimmy Barnes]].<ref name="biography"/> Energy Orchard disbanded in 1996 with a farewell London gig on [[St Patrick's Day]] which would be recorded for the live album ''Orchardville''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-interview|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy interview|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130703012528/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-interview|archive-date=3 July 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref>

==Solo career==
===''Domestic Blues'' and Steve Earle (1998–2000)===
{{Main|Domestic Blues}}
After Energy Orchard split up, Kennedy received a phone call from [[Steve Earle]], who offered to produce Kennedy's first solo record.<ref name="Loose">{{cite web|url=http://loosemusic.com/bapkennedy/index.html|publisher=loosemusic.com|title=Bap Kennedy: The Big Picture|accessdate=27 January 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081222080116/http://www.loosemusic.com/bapkennedy/index.html|archivedate=22 December 2008}}</ref> Shortly afterwards, Kennedy joined him in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and recorded his first solo album.<ref name="artistdirect"/>

''[[Domestic Blues]]'', which was released in 1998, was produced by the "Twang Trust" of Earle and [[Ray Kennedy (country singer)|Ray Kennedy]],<ref name="allmusic Domestic Blues">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/domestic-blues-mw0000598926|publisher=AllMusic|title=Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and Earle played guitar and sang backing vocals on the record.<ref name="biography"/> The album also features [[slide guitar]] player [[Jerry Douglas]], guitarist [[Peter Rowan]] and singer [[Nanci Griffith]] amongst its session musicians.<ref name="Loose"/>

All the songs on ''Domestic Blues'' were written by Kennedy except ''Angel is the Devil'' which was written by Earle.<ref name="biography"/> Earle was later to describe Kennedy as "the best songwriter I ever saw".<ref name="biography"/> The album was released on Earle's record label [[E-Squared Records|E-Squared]] and received generally favorable reviews.<ref name="artistdirect"/><ref name="allmusic Domestic Blues"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-domestic-blues.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120002203/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-domestic-blues.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> It was also a commercial success, charting at number eight on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].<ref name="biography"/>

Several songs from the album were used for movie soundtracks, including ''Vampire'' appearing in the soundtrack for the [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nominated<ref name="IMDB">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0203230/awards|publisher=IMDb|title=You Can Count on Me – Awards|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> film ''[[You Can Count on Me]]'',<ref name="artistdirect"/> which also won the Grand Jury Prize at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].<ref name="IMDB"/> Three other songs from ''Domestic Blues'' were also used in the film ''[[Southie (film)|Southie]]''.<ref name="biography"/>

In 2012, the album's title track was used as the theme song for [[BBC Radio 4]] comedy ''Happy Tuesdays''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2012/06/bbc-radio-4-adopts-domestic-blues.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=BBC Radio 4 adopts Domestic Blues|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> After the release of ''Domestic Blues'', Kennedy toured with Steve Earle<ref name="biography"/> alongside other artists on the E-Squared label, including [[Cheri Knight]] and [[The V-Roys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earledisc.com/SED_E_Squared.htm|publisher=earledisc.com|title=E-Squared records discography|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103070509/http://earledisc.com/SED_E_Squared.htm|archivedate=3 November 2014}}</ref>

While he was in Nashville, Kennedy developed a keen interest in the music of [[Hank Williams]], whom Kennedy described as his "favourite song writer"<ref name="newsletter"/> and a major influence. After he had finished recording ''Domestic Blues'', Kennedy recorded an album of Hank Williams covers entitled ''Hillbilly Shakespeare'',<ref name="artistdirect"/> which featured [[pedal steel guitar]] playing from [[B.J. Cole]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Hillbilly Shakespeare|others=Bap Kennedy|year=1999|page=4|type=CD}}</ref> The album had a very limited release as the first record on Kennedy's own label, Lonely Street Discs.<ref name="artistdirect"/><ref name="biography"/>

===''Lonely Street'', ''Serendipity'' and ''Moonlight Kiss'' (2000–05)===
After returning to the UK, Kennedy briefly managed an [[Elvis impersonator]] named The King, and was the producer for The King's album ''Gravelands'' – a collection of songs by other deceased artists performed in the style of [[Elvis Presley]].<ref name="cdbaby"/> The record became a firm favourite of [[John Peel]] and the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]]. Kennedy's continued interest in the music of [[Hank Williams]] and [[Elvis Presley]] led to him writing ''Lonely Street'', a [[concept album]] based on the lives of his two musical heroes.<ref name="artistdirect"/>

The album, which was released in 2000 on Kennedy's Lonely Street Discs label,<ref name="cdbaby"/> features bass guitar playing by [[Herbie Flowers]],<ref name="biography"/> who is noted for playing the famous bass line on [[Lou Reed]]'s hit song [[Walk on the Wild Side (Lou Reed song)|Walk on the Wild Side]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/bass/the-25-best-basslines-of-all-time-509265/10/1|work=MusicRadar|title=The 25 best basslines of all time (page 11 of 25)|accessdate=8 July 2016}}</ref> It received generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lonely-street-mw0000061425|publisher=AllMusic|title=Lonely Street – Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-lonely-street.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Lonely Street|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131118195406/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-lonely-street.html|archivedate=18 November 2013}}</ref> Kennedy's ballad "Moonlight Kiss" from the album was later used in the soundtrack for hit Hollywood movie [[Serendipity (movie)|Serendipity]] (starring [[John Cusack]] and [[Kate Beckinsale]]).<ref name="biography"/>

Following the release of Lonely Street, Kennedy spent several years touring,<ref name="Boogaloo songkick">{{cite web|url= http://www.songkick.com/concerts/10843678-pete-doherty-at-boogaloo|publisher=songkick.com|title=Pete Doherty at Boogaloo|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="Putney songkick">{{cite web|url= http://www.songkick.com/concerts/7448786-bap-kennedy-at-half-moon-putney|publisher=songkick.com|title=Bap Kennedy at Half Moon, Putney|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> including performances with [[Shane MacGowan]] of [[The Pogues]] and [[Pete Doherty]] of [[The Libertines]],<ref name="Boogaloo songkick"/> and at the respected [[The Half Moon, Putney|Half Moon, Putney]],<ref name="Putney songkick"/> which also regularly held the [[Rolling Stones]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.halfmoon.co.uk/static/music|publisher=halfmoon.co.uk|title=The Half Moon|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212065858/http://www.halfmoon.co.uk/static/music|archivedate=12 February 2013}}</ref>

===''The Big Picture'', Van Morrison and Shane MacGowan (2005–09)===
{{Main|The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)}}
[[The Pogues]]' lead singer [[Shane MacGowan]] provided guest vocals on Kennedy's next album, [[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]], with MacGowan providing lead vocals on the last verse of Kennedy's song "On the Mighty Ocean Alcohol".<ref name="fame magazine">{{cite web|url=http://www.famemagazine.co.uk/2009/06/05/bap-kennedy-goes-to-glasto/|publisher=famemagazine.co.uk|title= Bap Kennedy Goes to Glasto|accessdate=5 June 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629175600/http://www.famemagazine.co.uk/2009/06/05/bap-kennedy-goes-to-glasto|archivedate=29 June 2009}}</ref>

The late [[Carolyn Cassady]], another guest vocalist on the album,<ref name="Loose"/> was the basis of the character Camille in [[Jack Kerouac]]'s book ''[[On the Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/carolyn-cassady-camille-in-kerouacs-novel-on-the-road-8835425.html|work=The Independent|title=Carolyn Cassady: 'Camille' in Kerouac's novel 'On The Road'|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> At the end of Kennedy's song Moriarty's Blues, Cassady gave a reading from her own book ''[[Off the Road]]''.<ref name="biography"/> "Moriarty's Blues" is a ballad about the ''On the Road'' character Dean Moriarty,<ref name="biography"/> which was based on Cassady's husband [[Neal Cassady|Neal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/jan/18/beat-poets-cassady-kerouac-ginsberg|work=The Guardian|title=Neal Cassady: Drug-taker. Bigamist. Family man.|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

The Big Picture was also a return to working with [[Van Morrison]],<ref name="artistdirect"/> who had supported Kennedy since his [[Energy Orchard]] days.<ref name="biography"/> The album was recorded at Morrison's studio and featured the song Milky Way which was co-written by Morrison and Kennedy.<ref name="fame magazine"/> The musicians appearing on the album include [[pedal steel]] guitarist [[B.J. Cole]] and guitarist James Walbourne,<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=The Big Picture|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2005|page=2|type=CD}}</ref> who is a member of rock group [[The Pretenders]].<ref name="biography"/> The album was released in 2005 to generally positive reviews.<ref name="Loose"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-big-picture.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About The Big Picture|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001102/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-big-picture.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref>

After the release of the album, Kennedy was approached by former [[Dire Straits]] frontman [[Mark Knopfler]], who asked Kennedy to play as Knopfler's support artist.<ref name="artistdirect"/> This led to Kennedy working as the support artist and special guest for Knopfler's tours of the US and Europe, including a five night stint at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]].<ref name="fame magazine"/>

===''Howl On'' and Glastonbury(2009–2012)===
{{Main|Howl On}}
Kennedy's 2009 album ''[[Howl On]]'' was, like ''Lonely Street'', a [[concept album]] based upon a real life subject which Kennedy was interested in. ''Howl On'' was a look back at the [[Space Race]] of the late 1960s, with Kennedy examining the lives and backgrounds of the astronauts and scientists who worked on the [[Apollo program]].<ref name="fame magazine"/>

The only cover on the album,<ref name="Howl on notes">{{cite AV media notes|title=Howl On|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2009|page=Inside album front cover|type=CD}}</ref> [[Hey Joe]] was also chosen as a nod to this time period, as it had been the last song performed by [[Jimi Hendrix]] at the [[Woodstock Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/jimi-hendrix/1969/max-yasgurs-farm-bethel-ny-13d6b511.html|publisher=setlist.fm|title=Jimi Hendrix setlist at woodstock|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

The song also features guest guitarist [[Henry McCullough]],<ref name="fame magazine"/> who was, as a member of [[Joe Cocker]]'s band, the only Irishman to play at Woodstock.<ref name="McCullough">{{cite web|url= http://ultimateclassicrock.com/wings-and-joe-cocker-guitarist-henry-mccullough-suffered-brain-damage/|publisher=ultimateclassicrock.com|title=Wings and Joe Cocker guitarist Henry McCullough suffered brain damage |accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> McCullough also worked with [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Wings (band)|Wings]].<ref name="McCullough"/>

Howl on received generally positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/jul/19/bap-kennedy-howl-on|work=The Guardian|title=Bap Kennedy – Howl On|date=18 July 2009|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="about Howl On">{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-howl-on.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About Howl On|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001055/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-howl-on.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> The album was followed by a successful tour of the UK, Europe and America, including the [[South by South West]] festival<ref name="biography"/> and a performance at the 2009 [[Glastonbury Festival]].<ref name="fame magazine"/>

===''The Sailor's Revenge'' and Mark Knopfler (2012–14)===
{{Main|The Sailor's Revenge}}
Kennedy recorded a new album in early 2011, entitled ''[[The Sailor's Revenge]]'', produced by former [[Dire Straits]] frontman [[Mark Knopfler]]<ref name="artistdirect"/> at Knopfler's [[British Grove Studios]] in London.<ref name="Guy Fletcher">{{cite web|url=http://www.guyfletcher.co.uk/index.php/diary/Bap_Kennedy_sessions |publisher=guyfletcher.co.uk |title=Bap Kennedy sessions |accessdate=3 March 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215084628/http://www.guyfletcher.co.uk/index.php/diary/Bap_Kennedy_sessions |archivedate=15 December 2012 }}</ref> The album was a close collaboration between Kennedy and Knopfler, with the two artists having worked together on the project for 2 years. As well as producing the record, Knopfler had been heavily involved in choosing which songs to record for the album,<ref name="biography"/> and also played guitar on multiple songs and sang backing vocals for the song "Celtic Sea".<ref name="TSR notes">{{cite AV media notes|title=The Sailor's Revenge|others=Bap Kennedy|year=2012|page=Inside album front cover|type=CD}}</ref>

The album features several members of Knopfler's touring band, such as [[Glenn Worf]], [[Guy Fletcher]], [[John McCusker]], [[Michael McGoldrick]] and [[Richard Bennett (guitarist)|Richard Bennett]]. Also playing on the album were session musician [[Jerry Douglas]], who had previously worked with Kennedy on ''[[Domestic Blues]]'', and James Walbourne of [[The Pretenders]], who had played on Kennedy's 2005 album ''[[The Big Picture (Bap Kennedy album)|The Big Picture]]''.<ref name="biography"/>

''The Sailor's Revenge'' was released in 2012 on [[Proper Records]] and received widespread critical acclaim internationally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/162141-bap-kennedy-the-sailors-revenge|work=PopMatters|title=Bap Kennedy – The Sailor's Revenge|date=3 September 2012|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2012/06/pittsburgh-daily-news-usa-highly-commends-the-sailors-revenge.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Pittsburgh Daily News USA highly commends TSR|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> including No 1 – Best of 2012 in influential American magazine ''[[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-sailors-revenge.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=About The Sailor's Revenge|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120001107/http://www.bapkennedy.com/about-the-sailors-revenge.html|archivedate=20 November 2013}}</ref> where it was described as "truly a masterpiece from a man who is finally comfortable in his place in the world – The Celtic [[Blood on the Tracks]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-the-sailor-s-revenge-disc-review|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy – The Sailor's Revenge (disc review)|accessdate=3 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309113256/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-the-sailor-s-revenge-disc-review|archive-date=9 March 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> It was also listed by ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]'' in the Top 10 [[Americana (music)|Americana]] albums of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/01/the-sailors-revenge-makes-mojos-top-10-for-2012-americana.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=The Sailor's Revenge makes Mojo's Top 10 for 2012 Americana|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

The album was supported by tours of the US, UK and Europe with Mark Knopfler.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/07/bap-mark-knopfler-nimes-france.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Bap & Mark Knopfler – Nimes, France|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2013/06/bap-steve-earle.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Bap & Steve Earle – old friends reunited!|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

===''Let's Start Again'' (2014–2016)===
After the Celtic melancholy of ''The Sailor's Revenge'', Kennedy moved to an upbeat Americana style for the follow-up ''Let's Start Again''.<ref name="Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014"/> The album, which Kennedy recorded in his native [[Northern Ireland]],<ref name="artistdirect"/> was produced by Mudd Wallace,<ref name="Irish World">{{cite web|url=http://www.theirishworld.com/?p=6136|publisher=theirishworld.com|title=A Belfast Bap|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> who produced several albums for Northern Irish [[alternative rock]] band [[Therapy?]].<ref name="Mudd Wallace discogs">{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/539388-Mudd-Wallace|publisher=discogs|title=Mudd Wallace|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> Wallace was a long-time friend of Kennedy and had worked as producer for Kennedy's early band 10 Past 7.<ref name="Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014"/> Let's Start Again uses local Northern Irish session musicians, and features several musicians from Kennedy's live band, including his wife Brenda Kennedy, who plays bass guitar and sings backing vocals on the album.<ref name="Irish World"/>

The album had a full international release on CD and [[vinyl record|vinyl]] formats by [[Proper Records]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/post/2014/02/lets-start-again-international-release-dates.html 
|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Let's Start Again international release dates|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and has received widespread critical acclaim including a 5 star review from [[No Depression (magazine)|No Depression]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/reviews.html|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Reviews|accessdate=3 March 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321203701/http://www.bapkennedy.com/reviews.html|archivedate=21 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-let-s-start-again|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140304095143/http://www.nodepression.com/profiles/blogs/bap-kennedy-let-s-start-again|url-status=dead|archive-date=4 March 2014|publisher=nodepression.com|title=Bap Kennedy – Let's Start Again (album review)|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

=== ''Reckless Heart'' (2016) ===
Kennedy's final album, Reckless Heart, was recorded in early 2016, only a few weeks before his diagnosis.<ref name="biography" /> Like Let's Start Again, Reckless Heart was recorded in Northern Ireland and used several musicians from Kennedy's live band, including his wife Brenda.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reckless Heart (liner notes)|last=Bap Kennedy}}</ref>

The album was released posthumously by Kennedy's label Lonely Street Discs, in conjunction with Last Chance Records in the US and by at the Helm in the UK and internationally.<ref name="biography" /> It has received widespread critical acclaim.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/reckless-heart-review.html|title=Reckless Heart Review|website=Bap Kennedy|access-date=12 February 2017|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213090423/http://www.bapkennedy.com/reckless-heart-review.html|archivedate=13 February 2017}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Martin Christopher Kennedy was born on 17 June 1962<ref name="artistdirect"/> to Lily and Jim Kennedy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/BapKennedy/photos/a.231500228007.134233.128493593007/10151926758983008/?type=1|publisher=facebook.com|title=Bap Kennedy facebook post|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>{{Primary source inline|date=June 2020}}

He was the brother of [[Brian Kennedy (singer)|Brian Kennedy]]. The family grew up on the [[Falls Road, Belfast]], in the 1970s,<ref name="biography"/> where he got his nickname of Bap, as a childhood reference to the rolls (or "baps") of bread sold by local firm Kennedy's Bakery.<ref name="Irish World"/>

Kennedy grew up in West Belfast at the height of [[the Troubles]],<ref name="Irish World"/> and his close friend and 10 Past 7 manager Mark Kelly,{{small|[[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]}} lost both legs in a no-warning bomb in Belfast in 1976.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/mediacentre/press/2012/81136_unique_research_reveals_the_forgotten_needs_of_those_physically_injured_victims_of_the_troubles_and_their_families.htm 
|publisher=surrey.ac.uk|title=Unique research reveals the forgotten needs of those physically injured victims of the troubles and their families|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref>

Kennedy left [[Northern Ireland]] in 1985<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/6/category/pressinterviews/1.html 
|publisher=bapkennedy.com|title=Joe Giltrapp interviews Bap Kennedy|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> and worked as a [[labourer]] on building sites in London prior to becoming a professional musician.<ref name="Culture Northern Ireland">{{cite web|url=http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/article.aspx?art_id=65 |publisher=culturenorthernireland.org |title=My Cultural Life: Bap Kennedy |accessdate=3 March 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080310234504/http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/article.aspx?art_id=65 |archivedate=10 March 2008 }}</ref> While living in England, Kennedy became a qualified diamond [[gemology|gemmologist]], accredited by the [[Gemmological Association of Great Britain]].<ref name="Culture Northern Ireland"/>

In 2007, Kennedy moved back to his native Northern Ireland.<ref name="biography"/> Shortly after returning, Kennedy hosted a songwriting workshop, where he met author and former lawyer Brenda Boyd, who was participating in the workshop. The two soon became a couple, and they were married in 2008.<ref name="fame magazine"/> Brenda, who has written several advice books for parents of children with [[autism]] and [[Asperger syndrome]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/weekend/we-make-sweet-music-together-28480290.html|work=The Belfast Telegraph|title=We Make Sweet Music Together|accessdate=3 March 2013}}</ref> has since sung backing vocals on four of Kennedy's albums – ''Howl On'',<ref name="Howl on notes"/> ''The Sailor's Revenge'',<ref name="TSR notes"/> ''Let's Start Again'' and ''Reckless Heart''<ref name="biography"/> – and was also a regular member of Kennedy's live band, as his bass guitarist and backing singer.<ref name="artistdirect"/>

Through his marriage to Brenda, Kennedy was also stepfather to Christine White and Kenneth Hall, who is also an author, having written about his experience as a child with [[Asperger syndrome]] in ''Asperger Syndrome, the Universe and Everything''.<ref name="biography"/> As a result of his family's links with [[autism]] and [[Asperger's syndrome]], Kennedy became co-patron (with his wife) of the charity Autism NI in 2010.<ref name="Belfast Telegraph Feb 2014"/> Kennedy later revealed on his blog that he too had been diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome, which he credited as being "the engine of [his] creativity".<ref name=":0" /> Outside of music, Kennedy had a keen interest in the [[Apollo space program]],<ref name="about Howl On"/> which would be the inspiration for Kennedy's 2009 album ''Howl On''.<ref name="biography"/>

==Cancer battle==
In May 2016, Kennedy started a blog on his personal website, detailing his progress after a sudden cancer diagnosis.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bapkennedy.com/baps-blog.html|title=Bap's blog|website=Bap Kennedy|access-date=12 February 2017}}</ref> He died on 1 November 2016 in Belfast in hospice care from [[Pancreatic cancer|pancreatic]] and [[bowel cancer]]. He had been receiving palliative care at Belfast's Marie Curie clinic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfastlive.co.uk/news/belfast-news/west-belfast-singer-bap-kennedy-12113184|title=Tributes after West Belfast singer Bap Kennedy dies at 54|first=Sarah|last=Scott|date=1 November 2016}}</ref>
